item.title: Man dies weeks after being struck by car in Monaghan
item.description: A 47-year-old man has died from the injuries he sustained in a road traffic collision in Monaghan earlier this month.

item.title: Áras candidates voice support for a united Ireland
item.description: All three Presidential Election candidates have said they would like to see a united Ireland in the future, when questioned while out on the campaign trail across the country.

item.title: Oregon officials, residents slam 'ridiculous' Trump order to send troops into Portland
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said Saturday he will send troops to Portland, Ore., "authorizing Full Force, if necessary" to handle "domestic terrorists" as he expands his controversial deployments to more American cities.

item.title: Govt to offer up to €10k for families to drop IP claim
item.description: Minister for Justice Jim O'Callaghan has signed an order that will see asylum seekers and their families offered up to €10,000 to drop their claim for international protection.

item.title: 'Best news' for Huntington's disease community comes with unanswered questions
item.description: An experimental gene therapy seems to show potential to slow the debilitating progression of Huntington's disease, a European biotech company that developed the new treatment says.

item.title: Hamas says it has not received US Gaza ceasefire plan
item.description: Israeli attacks have killed 74 people in Gaza in the past day, health officials in the enclave have said, while Hamas said it has not received US President Donald Trump's Gaza ceasefire plan.

item.title: ‘The UN is in a state of crisis’ warns Indian senior government minister
item.description: In his address to the General Assembly, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, India’s Minister for External Affairs outlined the failings of a “gridlocked” UN, whilst asserting the need for more international cooperation and a reformed Organisation.
item.source:markdown: In his address to the General Assembly, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, India’s Minister for External Affairs outlined the failings of a “gridlocked” UN, whilst asserting the need for more international cooperation and a reformed Organisation.

item.title: Russia’s Lavrov says UN as relevant as ever in ‘age of multipolarity’
item.description: Widespread violations of the principle of the equality of states are the cause of crises and conflicts, Russian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Sergey Lavrov, told the General Assembly on Saturday. Mr Lavrov added that the founding principles of the UN are as relevant as ever in today’s “age of multipolarity.”
item.source:markdown: Widespread violations of the principle of the equality of states are the cause of crises and conflicts, Russian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Sergey Lavrov, told the General Assembly on Saturday. Mr Lavrov added that the founding principles of the UN are as relevant as ever in today’s “age of multipolarity.”

item.title: Current world order ‘reflects a bygone era,’ says Cuban Foreign Minister
item.description: Bruno Rodríguez Parilla, in his address to the General Assembly on Saturday, said that there can be no effective global response to serious challenges because the current world order "reflects a bygone era, when most developing countries did not even exist as independent states."
item.source:markdown: Bruno Rodríguez Parilla, in his address to the General Assembly on Saturday, said that there can be no effective global response to serious challenges because the current world order "reflects a bygone era, when most developing countries did not even exist as independent states."

item.title: New drone sightings over Denmark's biggest military base
item.description: Unidentified drones flew over Danish military sites including its biggest base during the night, the latest in a slew of sightings officials have called a "hybrid attack" and hinted at possible Russian involvement.

item.title: NATO to increase Baltic presence after drone incidents
item.description: NATO has said it is upgrading its mission in the Baltic Sea with an air-defence frigate and other assets in response to drone incursions in Denmark.

item.title: 'No decisions' made over carers allowance in Budget
item.description: The Minister for Finance has said that "no decisions" have been made on changes to the carers allowance in this year's budget.

item.title: 2025 Ryder Cup Day 2 recap - USA 4.5 Europe 11.5
item.description: The action from the second day of the 2025 Ryder Cup where Team Europe began with a three-point lead over their hosts at Bethpage Black.

item.title: As it happened: Áras candidates campaign across country
item.description: Coverage of all today's developments on the Presidential Election as the three candidates go on the campaign trail in Dublin and Cork.

item.title: Trump administration asks U.S. Supreme Court to uphold order aimed at ending birthright citizenship
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is asking the Supreme Court to uphold his birthright citizenship order declaring that children born to parents who are in the United States illegally or temporarily are not American citizens.

item.description:

item.title: International Paralympic Committee lifts partial suspensions of Russia, Belarus
item.description: The International Paralympic Committee has lifted the partial suspensions of Russia and Belarus. The IPC general assembly in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday first voted against a full suspension for Russia by 111 to 55, with 11 abstentions, and then voted against a partial suspension by 91-77 (with eight abstentions).

item.title: Body found in search for missing fisherman in Donegal Bay
item.description: A body has been recovered in the search for a missing fisherman off the northwest coast.

item.title: McCarthy adds to family medal haul with World bronze
item.description: Jake McCarthy has won bronze in the men's lightweight singles at the World Rowing Championships in Shanghai.

item.title: Regina youth use art to express meaning of truth and reconciliation
item.description: The North Central Strong youth advocacy committee came together earlier this month at the mâmawêyatitân centre for an ink press workshop where they created linocut pieces that were pressed onto orange poster board cut into the shape of shirts.
item.source:markdown:
![A picture of orange shirts cut out and stamped with linocut art work](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7643863.1758836115!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/orange-shirt-trc-youth-art.jpg)
The North Central Strong youth advocacy committee came together earlier this month at the mâmawêyatitân centre for an ink press workshop where they created linocut pieces that were pressed onto orange poster board cut into the shape of shirts.

item.title: Moldova's high-stakes vote: Democracy v disinformation
item.description: Moldovan President Maia Sandu has told RTÉ News that Russia has tried to influence tomorrow's high-stakes parliamentary election in the country through a campaign of bribery and disinformation about the European Union.

item.title: 'Unacceptable' to ignore human crisis in Gaza - Obama
item.description: Former US president Barack Obama has said there is no military rationale right now for continuing to pummel what is already broken in Gaza, and he said it was unacceptable to ignore the human crisis that is happening there.

item.title: Pairings confirmed for Saturday's Ryder Cup foursomes
item.description: European captain Luke Donald insists making history on day one will count for little if his team do not go on to win the Ryder Cup.

item.title: PSNI arrests thousands under new domestic violence laws
item.description: Police in Northern Ireland made more than 5,000 arrests during the past three years under new legislation aimed at tackling violence against women and girls.

item.title: 99 Problems: Why Ben & Jerry's is at war with Unilever
item.description: The man who put 'Jerry' into 'Ben & Jerry's' has walked away from the company he co-founded in a dispute that many industry-watchers predicted 25 years ago, writes Adam Maguire.

item.title: West Bank: Tales of the dispossessed
item.description: Continuous expansion by Israel of settlements in the West Bank is pushing Palestinians out of their homes and move elsewhere. The pattern consists of settler attacks on Palestinian farms and villages, often aided and abetted, say locals, by the Israeli military.

item.title: Turbulence ahead as opinions clash over passenger cap
item.description: The war of words over Dublin Airport's controversial passenger cap shows no sign of easing up anytime soon, amid very conflicting opinions on what should happen.

item.title: Meet the brothers at war in House of Guinness
item.description: Are Northern Irish actor Anthony Boyle and his English co-star Louis Partridge the Liam and Noel Gallagher of House of Guinness?

item.title: Perrie on being a solo artist: You have to own the room
item.description: We chatted to Little Mix star Perrie Edwards as she prepared to release Perrie, her eagerly-anticipated debut album, about "starting from scratch" as a solo artist, learning to trust her intuition and her love for her former bandmates.

item.title: Amid threats of annexation, could Canada and Greenland grow closer?
item.description: Canada and Greenland already had plenty in common before facing threats of annexation from the White House — but all that attention could make for a timely reason to strengthen a key relationship. CBC's Emma Godmere traveled to Greenland’s capital of Nuuk to hear from residents about being in the international spotlight and pursuing stronger ties with Canada.

item.title: Language revitalization is in the cards for this northern B.C. First Nation
item.description: Cheyenne Kaiser-Conant, a member of the Prophet River First Nation in northern B.C., says that resources for learning the Beaver language are slim. That's why she helped create a new tool to help other learners like herself: a deck of playing cards meant to bring the language to life.
item.source:markdown:
![A close-up of a person's hands holding a playing card.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7642858.1758748843!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/beaver-language-cards.jpg)
Cheyenne Kaiser-Conant, a member of the Prophet River First Nation in northern B.C., says that resources for learning the Beaver language are slim. That's why she helped create a new tool to help other learners like herself: a deck of playing cards meant to bring the language to life.

item.title: SNL returns next week. When the show debuted, it didn't shy away from assassination talk
item.description: Donald Trump, who hosted Saturday Night Live twice before becoming president, has consistently complained about his treatment on the sketch comedy show. The show returns next week, and Trump's aggressive communications regulator will likely take notice.

item.title: Sask.-based group rematriating the buffalo at national museum
item.description: The Wahkohtowin Buffalo and Moose Hide Experience at the Canada Agriculture and Food Museum is inviting Indigenous organizations and members of the public to help prepare animal hides for tanning. It's part of the Ottawa museum's efforts to mark the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.
item.source:markdown:

The Wahkohtowin Buffalo and Moose Hide Experience at the Canada Agriculture and Food Museum is inviting Indigenous organizations and members of the public to help prepare animal hides for tanning. It's part of the Ottawa museum's efforts to mark the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.

item.title: UN sanctions on Iran loom after vote to delay fails
item.description: UN sanctions on Iran are set to be reimposed, Britain's UN envoy has said, after a Russian and Chinese Security Council resolution to delay them failed, prompting Tehran to warn that the West bore responsibility for any consequences after nuclear talks floundered.

item.title: Guinea Supreme Court confirms vote to change constitution
item.description: Guinea's Supreme Court confirmed the result of a referendum to approve a new constitution in the junta-ruled country, saying it was backed by an overwhelming majority of voters.

item.title: How a former FBI director ended up on Trump’s enemy list
item.description: In an apparent escalation of U.S. President Donald Trump’s attacks on his political enemies, former FBI director James Comey has now been indicted on criminal charges. For The National, CBC’s Lyndsay Duncombe lays out a timeline of how it got to this point.

item.title: MSF suspend activity in Gaza City amid Israeli offensive
item.description: Medical charity Doctors without Borders (MSF) said Friday it had been forced to suspend its work in Gaza City because of the ongoing Israeli offensive there.

item.title: Podcast: Rising authoritarianism, Kneecap and Eurovision
item.description: An expert in international relations has told RTÉ's Behind the Story podcast it is "extremely alarming" that Donald Trump has the full force of the US government behind him for another three years.

item.title: Sask. First Nations leaders demand answers from FSIN over audit into $34M of questionable spending
item.description: A group of First Nation chiefs and councillors who met in Saskatoon Friday accuse the leadership of the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations of refusing to address allegations of mismanagement.

A group of First Nation chiefs and councillors who met in Saskatoon Friday accuse the leadership of the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations of refusing to address allegations of mismanagement.

item.title: Ireland to prevent entry of Israeli ministers - Taoiseach
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has told the UN General Assembly that Ireland will act to prevent members of the Israeli government who are "engaged in the unfolding disaster in Gaza" from entering Ireland.

item.title: Woman fell off Cliffs of Moher avoiding puddle - inquest
item.description: A 20-year-old University of Edinburgh student slipped and fell to her death while walking at the side of a "huge puddle" on a muddy part of a trail beside the cliff edge at the Cliffs of Moher in May 2024, an inquest has heard.

item.title: McIlroy takes centre stage as Europe take control in NY
item.description: Rory McIlroy was at the centre of controversy and the action as Europe controlled the opening day of the Ryder Cup at Bethpage Black.

item.title: The Netherlands returns 'Java Man,' thousands of colonial-era fossils taken from Indonesia
item.description: The Dutch government has agreed to return thousands of fossils to Indonesia from a world-renowned collection, after a commission ruled they were removed in the colonial era "against the will of the people," the education ministry announced on Friday.

item.title: Increase in over-65s 'couch surfing' amid homelessness
item.description: The Simon Communities has said action is required now to tackle over 65s becoming homeless, before the situation gets out of control.

item.title: EU steps up 'drone wall' plans after Russian incursions
item.description: EU countries have agreed on the urgent need to create a "wall" of anti-drone defences, after airspace violations by Russia rattled eastern members.

item.title: Cree Nation joins bid to redevelop Hudson’s Bay building
item.description: The James Bay Eeyou Corporation and JHD Real Estate propose to transform the Hudson’s Bay building in downtown Montreal into a hotel, a museum celebrating Cree culture, and subsidized housing for Indigenous students.

item.title: Why the world is watching as China pledges emissions cuts
item.description: China, the world’s largest polluter, just made a historic move: for the first time, the country is pledging actual cuts to its greenhouse gas emissions. CBC's Johanna Wagstaffe breaks down what this means for global climate action and how it compares to the U.S. and Canada.

item.title: Key peace process adviser Martin Mansergh dies aged 78
item.description: Former minister of state and key Fianna Fáil adviser Martin Mansergh has died aged 78.

item.title: Gunman who blamed NFL for hiding brain injury dangers had CTE: medical examiner
item.description: The former high school football player who killed four people inside a Manhattan office tower that houses the headquarters of the NFL, was suffering from the degenerative brain disease CTE, New York's medical examiner said Friday.

item.title: Watch: Officials walk out as Netanyahu addresses UN
item.description: Scores of delegates exited the hall of the United Nations General Assembly as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu walked up to the podium to give his speech.

item.description: A total of 16,353 people in the State have been recorded as homeless, according to the latest figures from the Department of Housing.

item.description:

item.title: Russia: Zelensky 'threat' to hit Kremlin 'irresponsible'
item.description: Russia has accused Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky of making "irresponsible" threats after he said Moscow's top officials should check for bomb shelters near the Kremlin if the country does not stop its offensive on Ukraine.

item.title: Gaza: Four more hospitals shut amid ongoing Israeli offensive
item.description: The escalating Israeli military offensive in Gaza City continues to overwhelm medical professionals there, with four more hospitals forced to shut down this month alone in the north of the war-torn enclave, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Resolution to avoid ‘snapback’ of UN sanctions on Iran fails
item.description: The UN Security Council has voted down an effort by China and Russia to extend sanctions relief to Iran for six months under the nuclear deal – formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The so-called “snapback” mechanism remains in force which will see sanctions reimposed on Tehran this weekend, following the termination of the JCPOA. Follow our live coverage below; UN News app users can go here.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council has voted down an effort by China and Russia to extend sanctions relief to Iran for six months under the nuclear deal – formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The so-called “snapback” mechanism remains in force which will see sanctions reimposed on Tehran this weekend, following the termination of the JCPOA. Follow our live coverage below; UN News app users can go here.

item.title: UN warns time running out for families with terrorist ties stranded in Syria camps
item.description: Six years after the defeat of ISIL, also known as Daesh, tens of thousands of people with alleged or actual ties to the terrorist group remain detained in camps in northeast Syria in dire conditions that continue to worsen.
item.source:markdown: Six years after the defeat of ISIL, also known as Daesh, tens of thousands of people with alleged or actual ties to the terrorist group remain detained in camps in northeast Syria in dire conditions that continue to worsen.

item.title: Pakistan’s Prime Minister warns of regional tensions, calls for ceasefire in Gaza
item.description: Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif told the United Nations General Assembly on Friday that the world faces “testing times” marked by conflict, terrorism, and climate change, while urging urgent action for peace in South Asia, the Middle East and beyond.
item.source:markdown: Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif told the United Nations General Assembly on Friday that the world faces “testing times” marked by conflict, terrorism, and climate change, while urging urgent action for peace in South Asia, the Middle East and beyond.

item.title: Intensifying threat looms large as UN highlights the world’s growing nuclear arsenals
item.description: The UN Secretary General on Friday warned a high-level meeting in New York focused on ridding the world of nuclear weapons that the threat is only “accelerating and evolving”.

item.title: Netanyahu hails Israel’s ‘stunning comeback’ after 7 October attacks, vows to ‘finish the job’
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told the UN General Assembly on Friday that Israel had rebounded from “its darkest day” to deliver “one of the most stunning military comebacks in history,” declaring that his country will not rest until Hamas is eliminated and hostages are freed.
item.source:markdown: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told the UN General Assembly on Friday that Israel had rebounded from “its darkest day” to deliver “one of the most stunning military comebacks in history,” declaring that his country will not rest until Hamas is eliminated and hostages are freed.

item.title: ‘The extraordinary power of ordinary people’: World leaders spotlight youth as agents of progress
item.description: Young people are at the heart of the world’s most urgent challenges, and on Friday, their role in shaping solutions took centre stage at the UN General Assembly. World leaders spoke of the remarkable promise held by today’s generation, even as they acknowledged the persistent barriers millions of children and youth face in accessing education, healthcare and political voice.

World leaders spoke of the remarkable promise held by today’s generation, even as they acknowledged the persistent barriers millions of children and youth face in accessing education, healthcare and political voice.

item.title: UN Security Council blocks China-Russia resolution on Iran sanctions
item.description: A resolution to extend sanctions relief to Iran under a 2015 nuclear deal failed to pass in the UN Security Council on Friday.
item.source:markdown: A resolution to extend sanctions relief to Iran under a 2015 nuclear deal failed to pass in the UN Security Council on Friday.

item.title: Prime Minister of Barbados calls for defence of rules-based world order
item.description: Prime Minister Mia Mottley of Barbados on Friday told world leaders the survival of small States and global peace depends on preserving a rules-based international system.
item.source:markdown: Prime Minister Mia Mottley of Barbados on Friday told world leaders the survival of small States and global peace depends on preserving a rules-based international system.

item.title: World News in Brief: New declaration on NCDs and mental health, Khartoum shelter crisis, WFP lifeline in Ukraine, South Sudan rights update
item.description: World leaders have thrown their weight behind the first-ever United Nations global political declaration tackling noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) and mental health together.
item.source:markdown: World leaders have thrown their weight behind the first-ever United Nations global political declaration tackling noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) and mental health together.

item.title: China’s Premier Li calls for solidarity, peace and shared economic prosperity in UN address
item.description: Chinese Premier Li Qiang on Friday marked the UN’s 80th anniversary with a call for world leaders to defend multilateralism, reject “Cold War” thinking and step up cooperation in the face of global turmoil.
item.source:markdown: Chinese Premier Li Qiang on Friday marked the UN’s 80th anniversary with a call for world leaders to defend multilateralism, reject “Cold War” thinking and step up cooperation in the face of global turmoil.

item.title: CAB sells two homes linked to criminals for €250,000
item.description: The Criminal Assets Bureau has sold two properties linked to organised crime groups in Limerick and Longford for over €250,000.

item.title: Man charged over number of burglaries in Co Wicklow
item.description: A man in his 30s has appeared at Bray District Court charged over a number of residential burglaries carried out in Co Wicklow over the past 12 years.

item.title: No agreement on specific Budget measures yet - Donohoe
item.description: Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe has said that no decisions on any specific measures for the Budget have been formalised and that an agreement "won't happen until at least this time of week".

item.title: Holy See urges moratorium on autonomous weapons at UN debate on AI
item.description:
Addressing the UN Security Council, Archbishop Paul Richard Gallagher calls for a moratorium on lethal autonomous weapons and highlights the need for a human-centered approach to artificial intelligence.

item.title: African Cinema and the legacy of Guido Convents
item.description:
Guido Convents, a Belgian national who recently passed away, was a dedicated and pioneering scholar, film critic, historian, and anthropologist. Charles Ayetan, a Togolese media practitioner, film critic, and expert on African cinema, was a friend and colleague of Guido. He says that Guido Convents’ impact on African cinema is a legacy worth celebrating.

Read all

item.title: Cantwell aiming to 'leverage' World Cup goodwill
item.description: The IRFU's head of Women's strategy Lynne Cantwell became a World Rugby Hall of Famer last night but the Dubliner has been set the task of building on the 'Green Wave'.

item.title: Eurovision to hold vote to decide whether Israel can take part in 2026 contest
item.description: Countries including Ireland, the Netherlands, Slovenia and Spain have threatened not to participate in the Eurovision Song Contest unless Israel is excluded from the competition over the war in Gaza.

item.title: 2025 Ryder Cup Day 1 - USA 2.5 Europe 5.5 recap
item.description: Team Europe laid down an impressive marker on the opening day of the 2025 Ryder Cup in Bethpage, winning both sessions and taking a three point lead. Here's how it all went down.

item.description:
In a time of crisis in the Middle East and conflicts around the world, the film “How Kids Roll” – screened at the Vatican Film Library on Thursday – seeks to bring a message of hope and of a fraternity that, in the eyes of the young, is still possible.

item.title: Aid flotilla to enter international waters towards Gaza
item.description: An international aid flotilla was set to leave Greek waters and head towards Gaza, organisers said, defying warnings from Israel that it would use any means to block the boats' access to the war-torn enclave.

item.title: 'Disappointed' Macauley part of NFL Croke Park protest
item.description: Eight-time All-Ireland winner Michael Darragh Macauley says he is "disappointed" NFL action will take place in Croke Park this weekend and will be among those protesting at the event.

item.title: 'Europe has to defend itself,' says Humphreys
item.description: Fine Gael's Presidential candidate Heather Humphreys has said she does not agree with the comments fellow candidate Catherine Connolly made yesterday about European military spending.

item.title: McCarthy and Doyle claim bronze at World Championships
item.description: The Irish duo of Fintan McCarthy and Philip Doyle have claimed bronze in the men's double sculls at the World Rowing Championships in Shanghai.

item.title: 'He'd be proud' - Jack de Bromhead Equine Centre opens
item.description: A new centre which will give more children with visual impairments and additional disabilities access to equine therapy has been opened in Dublin.

item.title: Kneecap member's terrorism case in U.K. 'null and void,' judge rules
item.description: A member of Irish rap group Kneecap was charged too late with a terrorism offence for allegedly displaying a flag of Iran-backed Lebanese militia Hezbollah, a London court ruled on Friday, throwing out his prosecution.

item.title: Several dead in Israeli strikes on Houthis in Yemen
item.description: Israeli strikes on Sanaa killed at least nine people and wounded more than 170 yesterday, Yemen's Houthis said, a day after the rebels launched a drone attack on southern Israel.

item.title: As it happened: Arás candidates canvas for second day
item.description: Follow all the latest developments on the second full day of campaigning for presidential hopefuls Heather Humphreys, Jim Gavin and Catherine Connolly.

item.title: Starmer to reveal plans for UK digital ID card scheme
item.description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has said plans for a new digital ID held on people's phones will be an "enormous opportunity" for the UK and make working illegally in the country tougher.

item.title: Israeli PM rebukes nations over Palestinian recognition
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has sharply denounced Western countries for embracing Palestinian statehood and accused them of buckling under pressure from activists and others who have accused Israel of war crimes against Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: 'There's no escape': Woman speaks out on intimidation by teens
item.description: Jennifer (not her real name), who has been with her partner for six years, moved to Ireland earlier this year and says the abuse has tainted what was meant to be a fresh start

item.title: Proposed cuts that spurred Canada Post strike would hurt Manitoba communities, say rural leaders, grand chief
item.description: Manitoba First Nations and rural leaders say they're concerned about plans from the federal government to modernize Canada Post.

item.title: Danish airport closes again after reported drone sighting
item.description: A suspected drone sighting briefly shuttered a Danish airport this morning for the second time in a few hours, after the country's prime minister said the flights were part of "hybrid attacks" that may be linked to Russia.

item.title: Tánaiste discusses Irish-US economic ties in Washington
item.description: Tánaiste Simon Harris has met with US Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick in Washington DC.

item.title: Search for fisherman missing off Sligo coast ends for day
item.description: A multi-agency search for a fisherman missing off the coast of Mullaghmore, Co Sligo has been suspended overnight and is expected to resume tomorrow morning.

item.title: 3,935 individual Leaving Cert subject results upgraded
item.description: This year's Leaving Certificate appeals process has resulted in upgrades for 3,935 individual subject results.

item.title: Junior Cycle exam results to be released on 8 October
item.description: This year's Junior Cycle results will be released on Wednesday, 8 October.

item.description: This year's Junior Cycle results will be released on Wednesday, 8 October.

item.title: Why Canadian taxpayers spend millions on U.S. medical treatments
item.description: An exclusive CBC data analysis has found that since 2018, Ontario has spent over $200 million sending patients to U.S. clinics for procedures unavailable in Canada. The biggest expenditure under the program last year was a specialized cancer treatment called proton beam therapy — a treatment available in every G7 country except Canada.

item.title: This doctor takes us through a day at Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City
item.description: Dr. Nada Al-Rub is spending a month in working in hospitals around Gaza. She says Al-Shifa has little to no equipment and that she and her colleagues have had to make due with limited resources and very complex injuries.

item.title: Trump's Ukraine pivot: Backing away, or backing a winner?
item.description: The rationale for U.S. President Donald Trump's whiplash on Ukraine is being hotly debated in Europe and at NATO, where political leaders and experts are asking whether it's personal self-interest or an economical military strategy.

item.title: US: Those with trade deals exempt from new pharma tariffs
item.description: US President Donald Trump's latest tariffs targeting pharmaceuticals do not apply to countries that already have negotiated trade deals, a White House official has said.

item.title: Former FBI director Comey indicted on two charges
item.description: The US Justice Department has filed criminal charges against former FBI director James Comey, in a dramatic escalation of President Donald Trump's retribution campaign against his political enemies.

item.title: School secretaries, caretakers dispute back before WRC
item.description: Talks on access to pensions for school secretaries and caretakers have resumed at the Workplace Relations Commission (WRC).

item.title: 'Some progress' in talks over school secretary pensions
item.description: The Fórsa trade union has said that "some progress" has been made at talks on access to pensions for school secretaries and caretakers.

item.title: Terrorism case against Ó hAnnaidh dropped by London court
item.description: The terrorism case against Kneecap rapper Liam Óg Ó hAnnaidh has been thrown out following a technical error in the way the charge against him was brought.

item.title: 'Ludicrous' that professors can't be appointed at ATU
item.description: The inability of Technological Universities to appoint professors is causing significant regional imbalance that needs to be urgently addressed, according to the President of Atlantic Technological University.

item.title: 17% reduction in mortgages approved last month - report
item.description: The number of mortgages approved last month was down 17% on the figures for July.

item.title: Families of Americans killed in West Bank demand accountability and justice
item.description: Extremist Israeli settler violence against Palestinians in the occupied West Bank has recently been its highest since the U.N. started recording. Over the last two years, several Americans have allegedly been among those killed there. Amna Nawaz sat down with three American families seeking accountability and justice for the death or detention of their loved ones. item.title: Dublin Zoo to offer ISL-interpreted videos for visitors
item.description: Dublin Zoo, in collaboration with Chime, the national charity for deaf and hard-of-hearing people, has begun to offer Irish Sign Language interpreted videos for visitors through QR codes.

item.title: Probe into Blackwater fish kill finds no definitive cause
item.description: The inter-agency group set up last month to investigate the cause of the large fish kill on the River Blackwater near Mallow in Co Cork in early August has concluded its work, but says it has not been able to identify the cause of the fish kill.

item.title: Trump to put tariffs on cabinets, furniture, pharmaceuticals and heavy trucks
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said Thursday that he will put import taxes on pharmaceutical drugs, kitchen cabinets and bathroom vanities, upholstered furniture and heavy trucks, starting next Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. ambassador says Washington has to 'take a look' at airport pre-clearance, citing drop in Canadian tourism
item.description: U.S. Ambassador to Canada Pete Hoekstra said Washington may need to reassess airport pre-clearance as part of an at-times tense exchange during a forum with Canadian business leaders in Banff, Alta., on Thursday.

item.title: Former FBI director James Comey indicted on criminal charges
item.description: James Comey was charged Thursday with making a false statement and obstruction in a criminal case, charges filed days after U.S. President Donald Trump appeared to urge his attorney general to prosecute the former FBI director and other perceived political enemies.

item.title: Man jailed over online posts exposing asylum seekers
item.description: A convicted criminal has become the first person to be jailed in a landmark case for online posts which risked identifying asylum seekers in Ireland.

item.title: U.S. film company condemns edit of horror film in China to make a gay couple straight
item.description: A Chinese film company is being criticized for an apparent edit of a scene in the horror movie Together that swaps the face of a man for a woman to make a gay couple appear straight. Editing films for Chinese distribution isn’t new — but one expert says this isn't how it's usually done.

item.title: Police investigating death of Irish woman in Benidorm
item.description: Spanish police are investigating the death of an Irish woman in Benidorm. The woman - who died last week - has been named locally as Catherine 'Cat' Peckham, who was aged 65.

item.title: EBU to vote on Israel's participation in Eurovision
item.description: The European Broadcasting Union (EBU) has confirmed it will hold a vote in November on Israel's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest.

item.title: NFL 'looking forward to' hosting more games in Dublin
item.description: The NFL could return to Dublin again in the future, the organisation's Vice President and Head Of Event Operations, Jon Barker, tells RTÉ Sport.

item.description: Europe Editor Tony Connelly and cameraman Bram Verbeke report from the illegal Jewish settlement of Ma'ale Adumim after Benjamin Netanyahu announced expansion plans.

item.title: NFL Dublin: Greatest show on turf rolls into Croke Park
item.description: Eoin Ryan previews Sunday's clash between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Minnesota Vikings at Croke Park, the first regular-season NFL match to take place in Dublin.

item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned that the Kremlin will become a target and Russian officials should check for bomb shelters if Moscow does not stop its invasion of his country, Axios has reported.

item.description: Former First Minister of Scotland Nicola Sturgeon and football legend Martin O'Neill will be among Patrick Kielty's guests on Friday's Late Late Show on RTÉ One and the RTÉ Player.

item.description: A second man has appeared in court charged in connection with harassing a member of An Garda Síochána in Cork.

item.description: A commercial partnership between the Late Late Toy Show and the fast fashion retailer Penneys will not go ahead this year, RTÉ has confirmed in a statement provided to RTÉ Investigates

item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy entered the Elysee Palace in 2007, boasting hyperactive energy and a vision to transform France, but lost office after just one term and the ex-president is now set to go to prison in a spectacular downfall.

item.title: O'Leary calls again for passenger cap to be abolished
item.description: The chief executive of the Ryanair Group has renewed his call on the Government to abolish the passenger cap at Dublin Airport, which he wants scrapped before the end of the year.

item.title: Keep daa chief and fire the board, says Ryanair boss
item.description: The chief executive of the Ryanair Group has said it would be "absolutely unconscionable" to pay the daa chief executive a reported €1.2m to leave his role following a rift with the board of the semi-state.

item.description:
A drone attack in Haiti kills eight children at a birthday party, underscoring the country’s “multidimensional crisis” that puts children at risk, according to the UN. In the past ten days there has been at least one child victim every 24 hours due to gang violence.

item.description: The Food Safety Authority has recalled a batch of Café Sol pesto pasta and chicken over the presence of listeria.

item.title: United Nations blog: Beyond the podium
item.description: World leaders are gathering this week at United Nations Headquarters in New York at a time of global upheaval. Wars, poverty, human rights abuses and climate change are all issues that the 193 Member States will address with the UN at the centre of those discussions. UN News app users can follow here.

item.title: Gaza City suffering escalates as Israeli strikes inflict more heavy casualties
item.description: While the Israeli military’s assault on Gaza City ramps up, conditions in the south of the war-torn enclave are so cramped that displaced and starving Gazans are sleeping on rubble-strewn open ground, UN aid teams said on Thursday.

item.title: Mental health takes centre stage at the General Assembly
item.description: For the first time, mental health is the focus of an official meeting of the General Assembly on Thursday, with world leaders expected to agree on a set of principles designed to drive global action to help alleviate the symptoms of those living with a complex variety of disorders.

item.title: UN moves to close dangerous void in AI governance
item.description: The explosive growth of AI tools around the world has yet to be matched by effective, internationally agreed rules on how this powerful technology is governed. A high-profile event at UN Headquarters on Thursday is designed to bring effective global AI governance a step closer to reality.
item.source:markdown: The explosive growth of AI tools around the world has yet to be matched by effective, internationally agreed rules on how this powerful technology is governed. A high-profile event at UN Headquarters on Thursday is designed to bring effective global AI governance a step closer to reality.

item.title: Disarmament over destruction: A renewed push for a world without nuclear weapons
item.description: Nuclear weapons continue to pose an existential threat to humanity. On Friday in New York as high-level week draws to a close, world leaders will revisit the grave dangers these weapons pose and push for renewed global efforts to eliminate them.

item.title: Yemen calls for ‘firm international action’ to counter global threat posed by Houthis
item.description: Yemen’s President Rashad Mohammed Al-Alimi on Thursday urged the international community to move beyond statements, to “firm international action” against Houthi separatists, saying the crisis provoked by the militants’ international aggression now threatens regional and global security.
item.source:markdown: Yemen’s President Rashad Mohammed Al-Alimi on Thursday urged the international community to move beyond statements, to “firm international action” against Houthi separatists, saying the crisis provoked by the militants’ international aggression now threatens regional and global security.

item.title: Youth to UN: ‘Listen to us. Invest in us. Partner with us’
item.description: With nearly half the global population under 30, the UN continues to emphasise the indispensable role young people play in decision-making towards achieving a just, equitable and sustainable future for all.

item.title: Abbas rejects Hamas attack, urges world to recognise Palestinian statehood
item.description: Mahmoud Abbas, President of the State of Palestine, addressed the UN General Assembly on Thursday, declaring that his people were enduring a “war of genocide, destruction, starvation and displacement” at the hands of Israel’s military in Gaza.
item.source:markdown: Mahmoud Abbas, President of the State of Palestine, addressed the UN General Assembly on Thursday, declaring that his people were enduring a “war of genocide, destruction, starvation and displacement” at the hands of Israel’s military in Gaza.

item.title: Post-war Somalia proves multilateralism can make the world a better place, says President
item.description: In his address to the General Assembly, the President of Somalia Hassan Sheikh Mohamud outlined global challenges and shared the progress his country has made in the fight against terrorism, promoting inclusive governance and economic development.
item.source:markdown: In his address to the General Assembly, the President of Somalia Hassan Sheikh Mohamud outlined global challenges and shared the progress his country has made in the fight against terrorism, promoting inclusive governance and economic development.

item.title: ‘Africa’s voice is not heard’: Leaders issue call for equity, justice and courage
item.description: On the third day of the General Assembly’s high-level debate, African leaders delivered a resounding and unified message: the United Nations must undergo meaningful reform, and the global order must be reshaped to ensure fairness, equity, and representation for all nations.
item.source:markdown: On the third day of the General Assembly’s high-level debate, African leaders delivered a resounding and unified message: the United Nations must undergo meaningful reform, and the global order must be reshaped to ensure fairness, equity, and representation for all nations.

item.title: Libya’s territorial integrity and sovereignty ‘are non-negotiable’
item.description: The President of Libya’s Presidential Council upheld the principle of national sovereignty, unity and stability in his speech to the UN General Assembly on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: The President of Libya’s Presidential Council upheld the principle of national sovereignty, unity and stability in his speech to the UN General Assembly on Thursday.

item.title: Haiti demands a new international force and reparations from France
item.description: “This is the face of Haiti today: a country at war, a modern-day Guernica, a human tragedy.” From the podium of the UN General Assembly, Haiti’s transitional leader delivered a stark plea to the international community.
item.source:markdown: “This is the face of Haiti today: a country at war, a modern-day Guernica, a human tragedy.” From the podium of the UN General Assembly, Haiti’s transitional leader delivered a stark plea to the international community.

item.title: TB cases in Ireland expected to hit 300 this year
item.description: The number of tuberculosis (TB) cases in Ireland is expected to hit 300 this year, the highest number since 2018.

item.title: Putin playing 'chicken' in Eastern Europe, says Russian military expert
How a Russian oligarch imported a Canadian-made luxury jet despite sanctions
Cork boy to meet Obama again during ex-president's visit
item.description: A 14-year-old boy from Cork, who was taken from a crowd and cuddled by Barack Obama in Co Offaly in 2011, has been invited to meet the former US president during his visit to Ireland this week.

item.title: Watch: Balloon spectacle in Co Roscommon skies
item.description: The longest hot air balloon championship in the world has been taking place in the skies over Boyle, Co Roscommon this week.

item.description: The longest hot air balloon championship in the world has been taking place in the skies over Boyle, Co Roscommon this week.

item.title: Thousands of fans arrive for first NFL match in Ireland
item.description: Thousands of American Football fans are touching down in Dublin ahead of the first NFL match in Ireland.

item.title: UN launches probe over Trump 'sabotage' claims
item.description: The United Nations has told President Donald Trump it has launched a "thorough investigation" into what the US leader called "triple sabotage" during his visit to the organisation's headquarters.

item.title: Teenage DJ brings the noise to Dublin library
item.description: A teenage Dublin DJ and her fellow deck spinners have replaced the traditional hush of library silence with techno beats.

item.description:

item.title: Response to scabies at nursing home 'lacked coordination'
item.description: A poorly coordinated response to an outbreak of scabies at a Kilkenny nursing home led to non-compliance in infection control, according to an inspection report by the Health Information and Quality Authority.

item.title: US Bishops reiterate concrete solidarity with the Church in Africa
item.description:
The Bishops of the United States renew their solidarity with the Bishops and faithful of the African continent, praying that government officials and all people may work together to bring peace, justice, and security.

item.title: China announces its 1st detailed goal to cut emissions
item.description: China has announced its first detailed target to cut carbon emissions. It was among the new climate plans and pledges from 100 other countries at a leaders' summit Wednesday during the United Nations General Assembly focused on cutting fossil fuel emissions.

item.title: European soccer body UEFA moves toward vote to suspend Israel
item.description: European soccer body UEFA is moving toward a vote to suspend its member federation Israel over the war in Gaza, people familiar with the proposal told The Associated Press on Thursday.

item.title: UK secures Ticketmaster commitments after Oasis issue
item.description: Britain's competition regulator has secured formal commitments from Ticketmaster to ensure customers have the information they need when they buy tickets from the entertainment and event group's platform, the watchdog has said.

item.title: Sarkozy given five-year sentence over Libyan dealings
item.description: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been given a five-year prison sentence after he was found guilty by a Paris court of criminally conspiring with Libya over illegal campaign financing.

item.title: 'Nothing left' in Gaza, says doctor evacuated to Ireland
item.description: A doctor who had been working in Gaza until his evacuation to Ireland last week has said there is nothing left there.

item.title: China makes pledge to cut emissions for the first time
item.description: China has for the first time made specific emission cut pledges, though its goal of reducing planet-warming greenhouse gases to just 7-10% by 2035 is seen as far too modest.

item.title: PTSB cuts mortgage rates, makes changes to deposit rates
item.description: PTSB is to cut its fixed-rate mortgage by up to 0.2% and make changes to its deposit rates, including increases and decreases.

item.title: New communications network tested for first responders
item.description: A new communication network is being tested for first responders after older systems failed during Storm Éowyn earlier this year.

item.title: Surveys on school patronage rolled out 'in coming weeks'
item.description: Parents of primary and pre-school children are to be surveyed shortly on their preferences when it comes to schools' ethos and other matters.

item.title: Russia denies involvement in Denmark drone incidents
item.description: Russia has rejected "absurd" speculation about its involvement in recent drone incidents in Denmark, its embassy in Copenhagen has said.

item.title: Source of Denmark drones remains unknown, says military
item.description: It remains unknown who is behind a series of drone flights over airports in Denmark that have triggered security fears, Danish military intelligence said today.

item.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy sentenced to 5 years in prison in corruption case
item.description: A Paris court sentenced former French president Nicolas Sarkozy to five years in prison on Thursday after finding him guilty on a key charge in his trial for alleged illegal campaign financing by the government of then-Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi.

item.title: Denmark flights again affected by drone incursions officials call 'systematic'
item.description: Denmark said Thursday that drone incursions that briefly shut two of its airports and affected military installations overnight were hybrid attacks intended to spread fear, but that officials did not know who was behind them.

item.description:

item.title: Chickenpox vaccine to be made free for children aged one
item.description: The Health Service Executive has announced that the chickenpox vaccine will be made available free of charge for all babies born on or after 1 October last year.

item.title: As it happened: Presidential campaigns get underway
item.description: The three candidates are hitting the road on the first full day of campaigning in the Presidential Election.

item.title: Donegal exceed Kerry in football All-Star nominations
item.description: All-Ireland SFC runners-up Donegal have received more nominations than champions Kerry as the PwC All-Star football nominees have been announced for 2025.

item.title: Retailers and communities on the 'chaos' of anti-social behaviour
item.description: Anti-social behaviour has become a pressing issue in towns and cities across Ireland, with retailers, commuters and public transport operators all reporting disruptive and sometimes violent incidents.

item.title: Spain, Italy deploy vessels to protect Gaza aid flotilla
item.description: Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has said he will join Italy in sending a military warship to assist an international flotilla seeking to deliver aid to Gaza after it was attacked by drones off Greece.

item.title: Ireland to ratify CETA trade deal next year - Taoiseach
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said that Ireland will fully ratify the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada by next summer, following a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney.

item.title: More must be done to protect clean air in Ireland - EPA
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency has said that more needs to be done to protect clean air in towns, villages and cities across the country.

item.title: Dublin mayor defends Obama award amid boycott call
item.description: Former US president Barack Obama understands the importance of the honour of the Freedom of Dublin, the Lord Mayor of Dublin has said amid calls by some councillors for a boycott.

item.title: Tánaiste to meet US Commerce Secretary Lutnick
item.description: Tánaiste Simon Harris is due to meet US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick as part of a diplomatic trip to the US.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel, free speech and big money media
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel might be back but worries about free speech and press freedom continue.

item.title: Obama accepts Freedom of Dublin 'with great humility'
item.description: Former US president Barack Obama has said he accepted the Freedom of Dublin award, on behalf of himself and his wife Michelle, with "great humility".

item.title: New embassy 'next chapter' in Ireland-US relations - Govt
item.description: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Harris has opened the new Irish embassy in Washington.

item.title: Carney heads to U.K. in search of investment and partners — as pressure mounts to show results
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney heads to the United Kingdom Thursday to attract investment and strengthen ties that he argues are key to securing Canada's future. The Conservative Party argues Carney is running away from problems at home and has nothing to show for it.

item.title: What is this TikTok deal Trump keeps talking about?
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to sign an executive order Thursday to confirm that a long-awaited deal to divest TikTok’s U.S. operations from its Chinese owner ByteDance will meet the requirements set out in a 2024 law. Here’s what we know so far.

item.title: U.S. policy changes mean Canadian children with cancer are losing access to clinical trials
item.description: Canadian researchers say they've had to stop offering kids with cancer places in some clinical trials because of funding and policy changes in the United States.

item.title: Palestinian leader rejects Hamas role in governance
item.description: The Palestinian Authority's President Mahmoud Abbas has said Hamas would have no role in governing Palestinians and has affirmed his readiness to work with mediators to implement a Gaza peace plan.

item.title: US is an imperial power adding to volatility - Connolly
item.description: Independent presidential candidate Catherine Connolly has described America as an "imperial power" contributing to current volatility.

item.title: Irish economy is continuing to show 'resilience' - Ibec
item.description: Ibec says the Irish economy is continuing to show "remarkable momentum and resilience."

item.title: Noel's guitar, damaged when Oasis split, up for auction
item.description: A guitar, which belonged to Noel Gallagher and was damaged on the night Oasis broke up, is going up for auction, and could sell for half a million pounds.

item.title: Govt warned of 'damaging' economic effect of Budget spend
item.description: The Government has been warned of the danger of overheating the economy with its planned €9.4 billion spending increase in the Budget next month by the Economic and Social Research Institute.

item.title: The A-Z of the Ryder Cup
item.description: An alternative alphabetical look at the storied competition before it gets underway at Bethpage Black.

item.title: Island Lake First Nations focus on healing after girl critically injured by alleged abuse
item.description: The grand cief representing a group of First Nations in northeastern Manitoba says members have been left in shock after a young girl from one of their communities allegedly suffered “horrific abuse” at the hands of her foster parents last week.

item.title: Judge orders forfeiture of 'Dirty Harry' gun in post
item.description: A judge has ordered the forfeiture of a .44 Magnum "Dirty Harry" handgun that was discovered in a Dublin postal depot after a shipping blunder.

item.title: Audit recommends FSIN review policies after flagging $34M in questionable expenses
item.description: The Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations (FSIN) is being advised to review its policies on procurement, hiring, capital assets, accounting practices and expense approvals after a forensic audit of its books flagged $34 million in questionable transactions.

item.title: 23 renewable energy projects due in next four years
item.description: Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment, Darragh O'Brien, has welcomed the results of the latest national auction for new onshore wind and solar energy projects as part of the Renewable Electricity Support Scheme.

item.title: No one-off measures in next year's Budget - Donohoe
item.description: The Minster for Finance has insisted there will be no repeat of last year's once-off cost of living measures, but other permanent supports will be put in place in next month's Budget.

item.title: How volunteers are leading the desperate search for a missing Indigenous teen
item.description: Many of the searchers don't know 14-year-old Samuel Bird. All of them feel the pain of his disappearance.

item.title: West Bank locals report ongoing Israeli settler expansion
item.description: Europe Editor Tony Connelly and cameraman Bram Verbeke report on dispossession and settler expansion in the West Bank.

item.title: Behind the Story: Uncloaking the secrets of The Traitors
item.description: Following Tuesday's nail-biting finale of The Traitors, RTÉ's Behind the Story podcast spoke with two of the people behind the hit show to find out how it all came together.

item.title: Minister 'surprised' IPS paid 2 Johnnies €24k for podcast
item.description: Minister for Justice Jim O'Callaghan has said he was "surprised" that the Irish Prison Service paid almost €25,000 to The 2 Johnnies to host a podcast focused on recruiting people to be prison officers.

item.title: Skiing's governing body approves gender eligibility testing policy
item.description: Skiing's governing body approved a gene testing policy for gender eligibility in women's events Wednesday, but delayed a decision on letting some Russian athletes try to qualify with neutral status for next year's Winter Olympics.

item.title: Israeli tanks advance in Gaza as medics say 50 killed
item.description: Israeli forces have pushed towards the heart of Gaza City, placing at risk the lives of Palestinians who had stayed put in hopes that growing pressure on Israel for a ceasefire would mean they would not lose their homes.

item.title: US man who groped teenager in hotel sauna avoids jail
item.description: An American man who groped inside and outside a young man's shorts in the sauna at the Shelbourne Hotel in Dublin has avoided jail.

item.title: Watch: A quick runthrough of the presidential candidates
item.description: Now that nominations are closed, the official Presidential Election campaign begins with three candidates on the ballot paper.

item.title: Bethlehem Mayor meets Pope and appeals for hope and solidarity
item.description:
Bethlehem’s mayor greets Pope Leo XIV after the General Audience on Wednesday, and appeals for support to stop the war and preserve the Christian presence in the Holy Land.

item.title: Treaty 5 document, medals and Chief Berens's jacket reunited after 150 years
item.description: The signed Treaty 5 document, a Treaty 5 medal, and a jacket presented to original signatory Chief Jacob Berens were on display last week for the Summit of Treaty 5 Sovereign Nations at Lower Fort Garry National Historic Site, north of Winnipeg.

item.title: Hero's welcome home for O'Connor after 'amazing year'
item.description: Kate O'Connor is back in Ireland following her historic silver medal at the World Athletics Championship in Tokyo.

item.title: High drama and high ratings for The Traitors Ireland
item.description: The Traitors Ireland has finished its first run on RTÉ with strong audiences on television and RTÉ Player.

item.title: 3 dead, including shooter, in attack at Dallas ICE office
item.description: A gunman who wrote "ANTI-ICE" on an unused bullet killed two detainees and wounded another when he fired on an Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office in Dallas from a nearby rooftop before taking his own life, officials have said.

item.title: WATCH | Massive sinkhole opens in Bangkok road
item.description: A large chunk of road in Thailand's capital collapsed on Wednesday, leaving a big sinkhole that snarled traffic and forced people out of the nearby area.

item.title: 'It's piracy' - Irish woman on Gaza flotilla slams drones
item.description: An Irish activist who is part of the Gaza aid flotilla has said drones targeting their boats are an attempt to harass and intimidate them from trying to break Israel's blockade of the besieged Palestinian territory.

item.title: Tories request investigation into Starmer chief of staff
item.description: The Conservative Party has called for an investigation into the Downing Street chief of staff, Morgan McSweeney, claiming he sought to mislead a UK election watchdog.

item.title: Uyghur woman in Ireland details Chinese pressure and harassment
item.description: Around 200 Uyghurs live in Ireland, part of a minority of 12 million in China's Xinjiang region. The UN says they face possible crimes against humanity — and one woman says Beijing's repression has followed her to Dublin

item.title: Climate Summit 2025: The path to COP30
item.description: Floods in South Asia, wildfires across North America, and record-breaking heat in Europe have underscored what scientists have warned for years: climate change is escalating faster than the political response. Against this backdrop, the UN Secretary-General is holding a climate summit during the high-level week of the General Assembly, pressing nations to raise their climate pledges ahead of November’s UN climate conference (COP30) in Belém, Brazil.
item.source:markdown: Floods in South Asia, wildfires across North America, and record-breaking heat in Europe have underscored what scientists have warned for years: climate change is escalating faster than the political response. Against this backdrop, the UN Secretary-General is holding a climate summit during the high-level week of the General Assembly, pressing nations to raise their climate pledges ahead of November’s UN climate conference (COP30) in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: World News in Brief: WHO reaffirms safety of vaccines, appeal for Sudanese civilians trapped in El Fasher, DR Congo Ebola outbreak update
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) stressed on Wednesday that there is no conclusive scientific evidence linking the use of paracetamol – also known as acetaminophen – during pregnancy, with autism spectrum disorder.

item.title: ‘Iran has never sought and will never seek to build a nuclear bomb,’ President tells General Assembly
item.description: Iran’s President affirmed that his country has no intentions to build a nuclear bomb in his address to the UN General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza: UN agencies warn of escalating attacks, mass displacement and famine
item.description: UN agencies on Wednesday warned that civilians in the devastated Gaza Strip are facing escalating attacks, more mass displacement and worsening hunger.

item.title: We have no choice but to fight, Ukraine’s Zelenskyy tells world leaders
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Wednesday warned world leaders that international institutions are “too weak” to stop wars, urging more countries to join Ukraine’s security coalition and step up pressure on Russia.
item.source:markdown: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Wednesday warned world leaders that international institutions are “too weak” to stop wars, urging more countries to join Ukraine’s security coalition and step up pressure on Russia.

item.title: Shipping faces ‘stormy seas’ as trade slows and costs rise
item.description: Global maritime trade is entering a period of fragile growth, rising costs and mounting uncertainty, the UN trade and development body (UNCTAD) warned on Wednesday.
item.source:markdown: Global maritime trade is entering a period of fragile growth, rising costs and mounting uncertainty, the UN trade and development body (UNCTAD) warned on Wednesday.

item.title: Oceans dangerously acidic from carbon emissions, report warns
item.description: The latest Planetary Health Check report says ocean acidification has reached risky territory. Experts say it will reduce our oceans’ ability to absorb the carbon we emit and also weaken the shellfish species we depend on for food.

item.title: Sinking islands, vanishing forests: World leaders call for urgent climate action
item.description: From the rainforests of Central America to low-lying atolls in the Pacific and drought-stricken plains in Africa, leaders came to the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday with a common message: climate change is no longer a distant threat, but an immediate danger demanding bolder global commitments.
item.source:markdown: From the rainforests of Central America to low-lying atolls in the Pacific and drought-stricken plains in Africa, leaders came to the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday with a common message: climate change is no longer a distant threat, but an immediate danger demanding bolder global commitments.

item.title: UNGA hosts first ever development finance summit to boost SDGs
item.description: The words inclusivity, resilience, reforms – and many more coloured in green and blue – provided a bold, digital backdrop from artist Marsha Dunn for the first ever Biennial Summit for a Sustainable, Inclusive and Resilient Global Economy.
item.source:markdown: The words inclusivity, resilience, reforms – and many more coloured in green and blue – provided a bold, digital backdrop from artist Marsha Dunn for the first ever Biennial Summit for a Sustainable, Inclusive and Resilient Global Economy.

item.title: Syria: Return of millions brings hope but challenges remain
item.description: In just nine months, one million Syrians have returned home following the fall of the Bashar al-Assad regime last December, the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) reported on Wednesday.

item.title: New national climate plans unveiled at high-level summit ahead of COP30 conference
item.description: From accelerating the move to clean energy to planting acres of trees, leaders from nearly 100 countries announced or reiterated new national climate action plans during a meeting on Wednesday as part of the high-level week of the UN General Assembly.
item.source:markdown: From accelerating the move to clean energy to planting acres of trees, leaders from nearly 100 countries announced or reiterated new national climate action plans during a meeting on Wednesday as part of the high-level week of the UN General Assembly.

item.title: AI must not decide humanity’s fate, UN chief warns Security Council
item.description: Artificial intelligence holds vast potential but poses grave risks if left unregulated, UN Secretary-General António Guterres told the Security Council on Wednesday.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Guardrails urgently needed for AI on the battlefield, warns Guterres
item.description: Humankind can’t allow killer robots and other AI-driven weapons to seize control of warfare, the UN Secretary-General just told ambassadors in the Security Council. “Innovation must serve humanity – not undermine it,” António Guterres continued, briefing a high-level meeting on growing concerns over peace and security in the fast-evolving age of AI – and the urgent need for consensus over international regulation. Follow our live coverage below - UN News app users can click here.

item.title: Syrian President outlines reforms, pledges national renewal
item.description: Syrian President Ahmad Al-Sharaa used his debut at the UN General Assembly’s annual debate to outline a forward-looking agenda of reform and rebuilding, promising balanced diplomacy, transitional justice, and inclusive representation as the country turns “the page of a wretched past.”
item.source:markdown: Syrian President Ahmad Al-Sharaa used his debut at the UN General Assembly’s annual debate to outline a forward-looking agenda of reform and rebuilding, promising balanced diplomacy, transitional justice, and inclusive representation as the country turns “the page of a wretched past.”

item.title: Kenya’s Ruto demands permanent African seat on the Security Council, highlights support for Haiti
item.description: Kenyan President William Ruto told world leaders at the UN General Assembly on Wednesday that Africa’s exclusion from permanent membership of the Security Council is “unacceptable, unfair and grossly unjust.”
item.source:markdown: Kenyan President William Ruto told world leaders at the UN General Assembly on Wednesday that Africa’s exclusion from permanent membership of the Security Council is “unacceptable, unfair and grossly unjust.”

item.title: Significant reduction in most serious crime - CSO
item.description: There has been a significant reduction in most categories of serious crime according to the latest CSO crime figures published today.

item.title: And so it begins - Presidential Election gets real
item.description: The close of nominations on Wednesday signalled the official beginning of the Presidential Election campaign.

item.title: Connolly presidency promises 'compassionate diplomacy'
item.description: According to her campaign, Catherine Connolly wants to be "a president for all the people, especially for those often excluded and silenced". She has the backing of all of the left-leaning parties in the Oireachtas.

item.title: Hearsay evidence allowed in Soldier F trial, judge rules
item.description: A judge in the trial of Solider F, a former British paratrooper accused of two murders on Bloody Sunday, has ruled that hearsay evidence from two other former soldiers will be allowed.

item.title: Kremlin presses on in Ukraine, two killed in Russia
item.description: The Kremlin has said it had no choice but to continue its military offensive on Ukraine, as Moscow rejected US President Donald Trump's claim that Russia was a "paper tiger".

item.title: No security guarantees but 'weapons, friends' - Zelensky
item.description: There are no security guarantees apart from "weapons and friends," Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has told the United Nations General Assembly.

item.description:
Pope Leo XIV invites the faithful to join in praying the Rosary every day during October to invoke God’s gift of peace, and announces a Rosary in St. Peter’s Square on October 11 as part of the Jubilee of Marian Spirituality.

item.description: People are being reminded to check the register to ensure they are registered to vote in the upcoming Presidential Election.

item.title: 1 detainee killed, 2 others critically injured in Dallas ICE facility shooting: officials
item.description: A shooter with a rifle opened fire from a nearby roof onto a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) location in Dallas on Wednesday, killing one detainee and wounding two others before taking his own life, authorities said.
