item.description: Activists taking part in a flotilla seeking to break the Israeli blockade of Gaza said Wednesday that some of their boats were damaged by drones overnight while sailing south of Greece.

item.title: CHI due to be integrated into HSE by 2027
item.description: Children's Health Ireland is due be integrated into the HSE by 2027, it has been confirmed. It follows a period of controversy for CHI over governance issues and issues around spinal surgery and scoliosis waiting lists.

item.title: Typhoon Ragasa makes landfall in China after killing at least 17 in Taiwan
item.description: Typhoon Ragasa, the world's most powerful tropical cyclone this year, struck the southern Chinese city of Yangjiang on Wednesday after killing 17 people in Taiwan and lashing Hong Kong with ferocious winds and heavy rains.

item.title: As it happened: Three in Áras race as Steen misses out
item.description: Follow live as the Presidential Election officially gets under way after nominations closed at lunchtime.

item.title: 'Nothing funny' about Kirk death, says Kimmel on return
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel insisted he never meant to make light of Charlie Kirk's murder as he returned to his ABC show following a five-day suspension.

item.title: Watch: What your clothing labels really tell you
item.description: That tag in your T-shirt? It may not be telling you the full story.

item.title: 22% of pupils absent for more than 20 days last year
item.description: Over a fifth (22%) of primary school children were absent from school for more than 20 schooldays in 2023/24.

item.title: Eight journalists unlawfully spied upon by PSNI - review
item.description: An independent review has revealed there were 21 instances whereby eight journalists were unlawfully spied upon by the Police Service of Northern Ireland in an attempt to reveal their sources.

item.title: Italy sends navy assistance after Gaza flotilla attack
item.description: Organisers of a Gaza-bound flotilla carrying aid as well as a number of Irish and international pro-Palestinian activists said they heard explosions and saw multiple drones target some of their boats.

item.title: Packed hall as Trump goes off script on biggest stage
item.description: There wasn't a spare seat to be had in the gallery of the General Assembly, as people packed in to hear US President Donald Trump deliver a speak that covered war, climate and escalators.

item.title: Suppliers to major Irish retailers linked to forced labour cotton
item.description: Factories that imported hundreds of tons of cotton fabric in 2024 from two companies linked to a Chinese forced labour programme are supplying some of Ireland's major clothing retailers, an RTÉ investigation has found

item.title: School ceiling tells own story on the state of schools
item.description: On Monday, as Minister for Education Helen McEntee stood at a podium in a Dublin primary school to launch the State's new and ambitious primary school curriculum, it was difficult to ignore the smell of damp that pervaded the hall, and the state of the ceiling above her head.

item.title: How forced Uyghur labour could be woven into your wardrobe
item.description: Behind the 'sustainable' labels on Ireland's high streets, cotton from China's Uyghur region is still slipping through. RTÉ Investigates uncovers the routes of forced labour and the systems that fail to stop it

item.title: Dept asked to engage with schools on how to reduce costs
item.description: Minister for Education and Youth Helen McEntee has asked her department to engage with schools to find out exactly what their costs are with a view to finding ways in which they can be reduced.

item.title: 5 reasons why 'Traitors Ireland' was a hit
item.description: Last night, in a shock twist, the last three women faithfuls, Vanessa, Oyin and Kelley grasped victory over the treacherous Nick and Ben, in the finale of the RTÉ One hit show 'Traitors Ireland'.

item.title: Mary Wilson and Áine Lawlor sign off from Morning Ireland
item.description: Broadcasters Mary Wilson and Áine Lawlor have signed off on Morning Ireland on RTÉ Radio 1 for the final time this morning.

item.title: Garda Superintendents to air frustrations at conference
item.description: Garda Superintendents say they are frustrated in their work because they are constrained by bureaucracy, limited resources, and ever-growing demands.

item.title: Commissioner to expand plan for more gardaí on streets
item.description: Garda Commissioner Justin Kelly has said he is expanding a policing plan which will put more gardaí on the streets of Dublin and other urban areas.

item.title: Trump's autism announcement leaves Tylenol's parent company with PR crisis
item.description: After U.S. President Donald Trump linked Tylenol use during pregnancy to autism spectrum disorder, several health organizations refuted his claims. But the painkiller's parent company still has to do damage control.

item.title: Naskapi science fair champion off to Abu Dhabi for international event
item.description: Aiden-James Einish from the Naskapi Nation of Kawawachikamach in northern Quebec will participate in Expo-Sciences International as part of Team Canada for his project on Labrador tea’s anti-inflammatory power in arthritis management.

item.title: Iqaluit therapist pushes for Nunavut's private practitioners to be part of counselling service
item.description: A mental health therapist is calling on the Nunavut government to allow private practitioners who live in the territory to be able to provide therapeutic support through the federal Non-Insured Health Benefits program.

item.title: An emotional Jimmy Kimmel returns to late night after show's suspension
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel returned to the air on Tuesday, addressing for the first time a controversy that sidelined his late-night show and intensified the debate around free speech in the United States.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa lashes Hong Kong with strong winds
item.description: Super Typhoon Ragasa, the world's most powerful tropical cyclone this year, lashed Hong Kong with hurricane-force winds and torrential rain as the city shut down and more than 700 flights were cancelled.

item.title: Fresh flood fears as Taiwan typhoon death toll reaches 17
item.description: Residents in a Taiwan town where flooding from a typhoon killed 17 people are seeking shelter over concern of further disaster after a lake burst its banks, as Premier Cho Jung-tai called for an inquiry into what went wrong with evacuation orders.

item.title: EU ministers call for vote on suspension of Israeli trade
item.description: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Harris has joined the foreign ministers of Belgium, Slovenia, Spain and Luxembourg in calling for an urgent vote in the European Council on suspending parts of the EU-Israel trade agreement.

item.title: Record temperatures linked to human-caused climate change
item.description: New research by climate scientists at Maynooth University in conjunction with Met Éireann has found Ireland's record summer night time temperatures this year were made 40 times more likely by human-caused climate change.

item.title: Connolly, Humphreys, and Gavin confirmed in race for Áras
item.description: There will be three candidates running in the Presidential election, following the closing of nominations earlier today. Independent Catherine Connolly, Fianna Fáil's Jim Gavin and Fine Gael's Heather Humphreys will be on the ballot come polling day, after nominations closed at midday.

item.title: Mandatory waste recycling targets set to be missed - EPA
item.description: Ireland needs to recycle an additional 400,000 tonnes of waste every year to achieve its legally binding recycling targets, according to a new report by the Environmental Protection Agency.

item.title: The Traitors Ireland: A Final night of twists and turns
item.description: John Byrne recaps Tuesday's final episode of The Traitors Ireland, where the five remaining players battle it out on a long day when nerves are shred and mind games are played out. *Spoilers galore*

item.title: FAI criticised for responses to Oireachtas committee
item.description: The head of the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Arts, Media, Communications, Culture and Sport, Alan Kelly TD, has said the Football Association of Ireland did not adequately answer the committee's questions regarding safeguarding issues.

item.title: Traitors Ireland finale brings drama to Slane Castle
item.description: The first season of The Traitors Ireland came to a thrilling close on Tuesday night at Slane Castle, after 12 nights of suspicion, alliances and betrayals. Host Siobhán McSweeney presided over the tense final as the series wrapped up its debut run.

item.title: Fort Chipewyan Métis Nation rejects Alberta's oilsands tailings recommendations
item.description: The Fort Chipewyan Métis Nation is rejecting Alberta's recommendations for managing oilsands water tailings, alleging "industry bias, lack of scientific integrity, and the absence of meaningful Indigenous inclusion."

item.title: UN panel calls for Israeli international football ban
item.description: A panel of experts appointed by the United Nations has called for Israel to be kicked out of international football competitions.

item.title: Pope Leo: Recognition of Palestine helps, but dialogue is broken
item.description:
Responding to journalists' questions as he prepared to leave Castel Gandolfo for the Vatican on Tuesday evening, Pope Leo XIV reflected, 'If Europe were truly united, I believe it could do a lot.'

item.title: Watch: Who do the contestants hope will win Traitors?
item.description: Ahead of tonight's final of The Traitors Ireland, the contestants who have already left the game shared their predictions on who would go all the way.

item.title: Why are some Christians predicting the rapture on TikTok?
item.description: The Rapture is near, at least according to an apocalyptic prophecy by one South African man who says it will fall on Tuesday or Wednesday. His claim has gone viral and some believe it will mark the end times while others mock it on social media.

item.title: Kahnawà:ke community calls on public to help finish new cultural arts centre
item.description: While Kahnawà:ke’s leaders say the project is not in danger and should be completed by the end of the year, those behind the project are hoping to reach their fundraising goals as soon as possible.

item.title: Donabate post-mortem yet to establish cause of death
item.description: The post-mortem examination on the skeletal remains of a child found in Donabate last week has so far failed to establish a cause of death.

item.title: Man guilty of attempting to assassinate Donald Trump
item.description: A man charged with attempting to assassinate US President Donald Trump has been convicted by a federal jury on all counts.

item.title: LDA to become 'largest producer of homes' by 2028
item.description: The Chief Executive of the Land Development Agency is predicting it will become the country's biggest residential developer by 2028.

item.title: Yukon First Nation joins chorus against territory for disclosing draft mining framework
item.description: Russell Blackjack said the lack of co-operation and consent has upended negotiations, which he said are supposed to be in confidence. The territory, he said, is keeping with what’s routine: unilateral decision-making.

item.title: Attacks by Jewish settlers on West Bank village rising
item.description: Europe Editor Tony Connelly and cameraman Bram Verbeke report from Taybeh, a christian village in the West Bank where locals say they are facing increased attacks by Jewish settlers.

item.title: Tylenol, vaccines have no links to causing autism - WHO
item.description: Neither the painkiller Tylenol nor vaccines have been shown to cause autism, the World Health Organization have said, following comments from US President Donald Trump and his administration to the contrary.

item.title: Poland hosts 5th ‘Ecce Homo Congress of Young Consecrated’
item.description:
The experience of communion and the rediscovery of one’s humanity in the likeness of Christ are the central fruits of the Fifth Congress of Young Consecrated in Licheń, Poland.

item.description: Hurling's all-time top-scorer Patrick Horgan has announced his retirement from inter-county duty with Cork.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV to exorcists: Your ministry is necessary and delicate
item.description:
In a message to a meeting of the International Association of Exorcists, held just outside Rome, the Pope encouraged participants to accompany the faithful who suffer from evil through prayers of liberation and consolation.

item.title: 'Very close' to 88% of IP applicants crossing NI border
item.description: Minister for Justice Jim O'Callaghan has said that "very close" to 87.66% of people claiming international protection are crossing the border from Northern Ireland before claiming asylum here.

item.title: Indigenous-led think tank looks to expand northern focus with Yellowhead North
item.description: The Yellowhead Institute, an Indigenous-led think tank, wants to establish more of a presence across Dene and Inuit lands with research and writing on northern issues, including Indigenous governance, self-determination, land and resources, devolution, and modern treaty implementation.

item.description: A pensioner who preyed on vulnerable young women addicted to heroin by trafficking them into prostitution is to have his prison sentence increased by two years, the Court of Appeal in Belfast has ruled.

item.title: Holy See reaffirms need to combat all forms of violence against women and girls
item.description:
The United Nations hosts a meeting in New York to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the 4th World Conference on Women held in Beijing. item.title: US says it dismantled telecoms threat during UN summit

item.title: Watch: Macron calls Trump as motorcade blocks his route

item.title: Man found guilty of trying to assassinate Trump on his Florida golf course
item.description: The man accused of trying to assassinate U.S. President Donald Trump last year at his Florida golf course was found guilty on Tuesday.

item.title: MLB will use challenge system for balls and strikes throughout 2026 season

item.title: Net loss? Why Ireland trails Europe on marine protection
item.description: Marine Protected Areas are seen as a solution to biodiversity loss and dwindling fish stocks, but why has Ireland has yet to deliver the law to make them real?

item.description: Next week Standing Buffalo Dakota Nation in Saskatchewan will sign a memorandum of understanding with the Fort Peck Sioux Tribes community in the U.S to build a trade corridor system.

The war in Gaza is expected to dominate this week’s U.N. session as Israeli Forces continue in their campaign to occupy Gaza.

item.description: Weaknesses in the governance of the current home birth system creates a risk for expectant mothers and their babies, according to an internal HSE audit.

item.title: War in Ukraine: Order of Malta continues to ensure humanitarian support

item.title: Failure to end Gaza war undermining world’s credibility, UN chief warns

item.title: US President Trump criticizes UN, NATO and climate ‘hoax’
item.description: United States President Donald Trump told world leaders gathered at the UN on Tuesday that during a seven-month period he had ended “seven unendable” wars, but said the global body had offered little help.
item.source:markdown: United States President Donald Trump told world leaders gathered at the UN on Tuesday that during a seven-month period he had ended “seven unendable” wars, but said the global body had offered little help.

item.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Fragile diplomatic momentum on Ukraine must continue, Guterres urges
item.description: The UN Secretary-General told the Security Council on Tuesday it’s important not to lose the “fragile diplomatic momentum” between Ukraine and Russia – and international mediators – over ending the war. He was briefing ambassadors in back-to-back meetings where calling for ceasefire in Gaza, he said the “day after” war ends there, must be anchored in international law, rejecting any “ethnic cleansing” of Palestinians. Our live meetings coverage is below; UN News app users can click here.

item.title: ‘Our democracy is non-negotiable’, President Lula of Brazil tells General Assembly
item.description: The UN symbolises the highest expression of the aspiration for peace and prosperity but the ideals that inspired its founding 80 years ago are under threat as never before, Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula Da Silva told the General Assembly on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: The UN symbolises the highest expression of the aspiration for peace and prosperity but the ideals that inspired its founding 80 years ago are under threat as never before, Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula Da Silva told the General Assembly on Tuesday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Gaza and Nicaragua human rights update, WHO hypertension alert and alarm over US autism claim
item.description: The UN agency for Palestine refugees, UNRWA, has confirmed that between 11 and 16 September, 12 of its premises in Gaza City were hit directly or indirectly, amid intensifying Israeli military activity there.

item.title: Uphold founding principles and ‘be better together’: General Assembly President
item.description: As the UN marks its 80th anniversary, Member States must show the people of the world why the organization matters and uphold its founding principles in the decades ahead, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock said on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: As the UN marks its 80th anniversary, Member States must show the people of the world why the organization matters and uphold its founding principles in the decades ahead, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock said on Tuesday.

item.title: UN’s Guterres to world leaders: Choose peace and cooperation over chaos

item.title: Sudan war: Lifesaving cholera vaccination campaign begins in Darfur
item.description: Amid the devastating war in Sudan, UN aid teams are overcoming major obstacles to curb a cholera outbreak claiming lives across the country, with young children particularly at risk.

item.description: Speaking at a high-level briefing on Ukraine on Tuesday, the UN Secretary General António Guterres told the Security Council that the international community cannot afford to lose “fragile” diplomatic momentum over ending the war with Russia.

item.title: Haiti’s security crisis ‘is like the Sword of Damocles above us’: Foreign Minister
item.description: Foreign Ministers from across the Americas met on the margins of the UN General Assembly on Tuesday to rally for greater support for Haiti.

item.title: Echoes of Gaza war dominate UN halls, from Assembly podium to Council chamber
item.description: The deepening crisis in Gaza echoed through the halls of the United Nations on Tuesday, as the Security Council grappled with alarming reports of civilian suffering and rising regional tensions, while leaders from Jordan to Qatar took the General Assembly floor to demand urgent global action.

item.title: Guterres calls for ceasefire as European leaders affirm Ukraine’s rights at UN
item.description: The Security Council on Tuesday heard a warning from Secretary-General António Guterres on the war in Ukraine, while in the General Assembly, leaders from Lithuania, France and Poland called for stronger international action against aggression.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council on Tuesday heard a warning from Secretary-General António Guterres on the war in Ukraine, while in the General Assembly, leaders from Lithuania, France and Poland called for stronger international action against aggression.

item.title: At UN, Colombian President Petro slams global inaction, calls for urgent reform
item.description: In what he said will be his “last statement as president” to the UN General Assembly, Colombia’s Gustavo Petro delivered a forceful critique of global inequalities, migration policies and the suffering in warzones, charging that rich societies are turning blind to their shared dangers.

item.title: Sarah McLachlan performs after free speech stand as Jimmy Kimmel returns to some stations
item.description: The Canadian singer was a surprise guest as Jimmy Kimmel made an emotional return. Millions of people were expected to watch to see how the late-night ABC talk show host addressed his nearly weeklong suspension despite some stations not carrying the broadcast.

item.title: Barack Obama to receive Freedom of Dublin this week
item.description: Former US president Barack Obama is expected to accept the Freedom of Dublin at a ceremony in the Mansion House this week.

item.description: Comedy duo the 2 Johnnies got paid nearly €25,000 by the Irish Prison Service to host a show on the attractions of working as a prison officer.

item.description: The former Mohawk Institute — the longest-running residential school in Canada — is now called the Woodland Cultural Centre and is preparing to open to the public for the first time as a museum on Sept. 30, National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.

item.title: Nuncio asks for prayers and action for war-torn Sudan
item.description:
The closeness of the Pope and of the Church to the war-struck people of Sudan was at the heart of the Apostolic Nuncio‘s mission as he travelled to the suffering country to meet with the Catholic community there and engage with political authorities.

item.title: FAI confirm delegation will attend Oireachtas meeting
item.description: The Football Association of Ireland has written to the Chairman of the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Arts, Media, Communications, Culture and Sport Alan Kelly, confirming their attendance at a hearing of the committee at Leinster House tomorrow afternoon.

item.description: Israel's military pressed on with its Gaza offensive a day after dozens of world leaders gathered at the United Nations to recognise a Palestinian state.

item.title: White House shifts explanation on Tom Homan, U.S. border czar accused of taking $50,000 in a paper bag
item.description: The White House press secretary said on Monday that Tom Homan "never took" $50,000 US in cash from an undercover agent, after a damning report emerged over the weekend. Homan himself was less specific in his denial of wrongdoing in an interview with Fox News on Monday night.

item.title: Mission alive at 140 years: Legacy of the Missionary Sisters of the Precious Blood
item.description:
The Missionary Sisters of the Precious Blood (CPS) are celebrating 140 years of missionary presence, service, and witness, a journey that began in the hills of KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, and has since embraced the entire world.

item.title: Paracetamol safe during pregnancy - EU Medicines Agency

item.description: From dunking cymbals underwater to sampling archival Mi'kmaq voices, the acclaimed musician details how the Sk+te'kmujue'katik (At the Place of Ghosts) score came together.

item.title: Calls for more ambition in Irish language teaching
item.description: A more ambitious plan is needed to improve the way Irish is taught in schools, Conradh na Gaeilge has said.

item.title: Egyptian British activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah released after presidential pardon

item.title: Hamas offers Palestinian people 'no future' - Harris

A prayer vigil called “Peace for Gaza,” was organized in Rome by the Community of Sant’Egidio on Monday evening at the Church of Santa Maria in Trastevere, supported by a vast network of Catholic associations, drew hundreds together in prayer and featured the voices for peace and against war of Cardinal Gualtiero Bassetti and Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa.

item.title: Drones over Copenhagen shut Denmark's largest airport to air traffic for hours

item.title: Traitors Ireland: Best moments so far as final looms

item.description: After her shock murder on Sunday night's episode of The Traitor's Ireland, Amy has said she believes the remaining Traitors are still hiding in plain sight.

item.description: Super Typhoon Ragasa brought heavy rain and triggered landslides in the northern Philippines on Monday as it made landfall with sustained winds measuring 215 km/h and gusts of up to 295 km/h. One of this year's strongest typhoons, Ragasa is forecast to remain in the South China Sea at least into Wednesday while skirting south of Taiwan and Hong Kong before hitting the Chinese mainland.

This gathering served as a moment for prayer and a powerful display of solidarity in caring for creation, inspired by the encyclical, “Laudato Si’”. Additionally, the event was an opportunity for participants to advocate for peace in Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado Province.

item.title: Women for Peace: Voices of hope and humanity

"Women for Peace" is a unique concept-concert that unites voices from around the world to promote reconciliation, hope, and solidarity and peace. The initiative blends opera and storytelling to highlight women as agents of peace. It uses music as a universal language capable of bridging cultures, inspiring reflection, and sending a clear message: peace is not a luxury, it is a human necessity.

item.title: 30 years of advancing gender equality: Achievements, setbacks, and the road ahead

At this year’s General Assembly, UN delegates will reflect on the achievements made and raise awareness about the huge amount of work that still needs to be done.

item.description: The Security Council met in New York in emergency session on Monday after planes from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) intercepted three Russia jets in Estonian airspace last Friday, according to the Estonian Government. Referencing the intensifying attacks by Russia on Ukraine and reported casualties inside Russia, “the world simply cannot afford such danger to spiral out of control,” said Assistant Secretary-General Miroslav Jenča. Follow the meeting coverage live below, and UN News app users can click here.

item.description:
During his Mass at the Vatican's parish of Sant'Anna, Pope Leo XIV calls the faithful to an inner revolution of the heart, where one resists the inclination to serve 'two masters,' and prays rulers of nations may be free from the temptation to use wealth against humanity.

Read all

item.title: Large-scale Russian attack on Ukraine kills 3 people and wounds dozens
item.description: Russia unleashed a major drone and missile attack on Ukraine overnight, killing three people, injuring dozens more and damaging infrastructure and residential buildings, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Saturday.

item.title: More powers for HIQA to probe incidents at nursing homes
item.description: The Health Information and Quality Authority will be given additional powers to investigate serious patient safety incidents in public nursing homes.

item.title: Cyberattack disrupts major European airports, including Heathrow, Brussels
item.description: A cyberattack on a provider of check-in and boarding systems has disrupted operations at several major European airports, including London's Heathrow, the continent's busiest, causing flight delays and cancellations on Saturday.

item.title: Trump claims negative media coverage of him 'illegal'
item.description: US President Donald Trump has bashed US media coverage that he claimed was unduly negative and therefore "illegal," stoking a debate over free speech following the suspension of comedian Jimmy Kimmel's TV show by ABC.

item.title: Joy Crookes: 'I'm leaning into who I actually am'
item.description: We caught up with Joy Crookes ahead of the release of her second album Juniper, to chat about making her new record, navigating the music industry as a "pretty standard human being" and staying resolutely true to herself.

item.title: Cyber attack disruption at airports to carry into Sunday
item.description: A cyber attack at a provider of check-in and boarding systems disrupted operations at several major European airports including London's Heathrow, the continent's busiest, causing flight delays and cancellations.

item.title: Lord's Day Reflection: What is the Lord telling us?
item.description:
As the Church marks the Twenty-Fifth Sunday in Ordinary Time, Fr Edmund Power reflects on the parable of the unjust steward.

Read all

item.title: This First Nation helps keep tradition of sweetgrass harvest alive in Treaty 4
item.description: Members from a northern Manitoba First Nation known as the "land of sweetgrass" have travelled hundreds of kilometres to share their harvest of the medicine.

item.title: Myanmar Bishop: 'Civilians are suffering, just trying to survive'
item.description:
As the bloodshed continues in Myanmar and civil war continues to cripple the country, Bishop Peter Tin Wai of Pyay in the Rakhine state decries the tragic effects for innocent civilians, who are 'just trying to survive,' including for young people, who, being forced to enlist and fight, are determined to flee.

Read all

item.title: O'Connor wins world silver medal in heptathlon
item.description: Kate O'Connor won the silver medal in the heptathlon at the World Athletics Championships following an incredible fifth personal best from seven events, as she clocked two minutes 9.56 seconds in the decisive 800m.

item.title: Zelensky says will meet Trump next week at UN
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said he would meet US counterpart Donald Trump on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly next week as Russia intensified attacks across his country.

item.title: Three people killed in Russian air attack on Ukraine
item.description: Russia unleashed a major drone and missile attack on Ukraine overnight, killing three people, injuring dozens more, and damaging infrastructure and residential buildings, President Volodymyr Zelensky said.

item.title: €12 Budget pension hike rejected as Dept plays hardball
item.description: The framing of the budget has stepped up a gear in recent days.

item.title: What to expect at this year's UN General Assembly
item.description: World leaders will gather in New York next week for the UN's General Assembly. But amid spiralling global crises, funding cuts and diplomatic deadlock, some even wonder if the UN's 80th birthday could be its last. Here are some things to look out for this week.

item.title: 'I have survivor's guilt' - student from Gaza in Dubin
item.description: Ireland is to the fore in managing to evacuate students from the war zone in Gaza.

item.title: 5 takeaways from the National Ploughing Championships
item.description: After three days at the National Ploughing Championships, Agriculture and Consumer Affairs Correspondent Aengus Cox runs through five key takeaways from the event and the challenges facing farmers the length and breadth of the country

item.title: The challenges and risks of installing public toilets
item.description: A carved granite plinth with perforated metal roundels, wrought-iron railings with shamrock heads and a cast-iron ventilation shaft with stylised foliage located at the junction of Kevin Street and New Street and built around the year 1900.

item.title: Watch: Cork pair set to complete ultramarathon challenge
item.description: Two Cork men are aiming to complete an epic endurance challenge in aid of the Irish Cancer Society this weekend.

item.title: On top of widespread violence and hunger, South Sudan now reeling from U.S. aid cuts
item.description: As of 2024, nine million people in South Sudan, or more than 70 per cent of the population, were dependent on some form of foreign assistance, according to the UN. Now, that dependence is colliding with shrinking resources and a hunger crisis.

item.title: South Sudan reeling from U.S. aid cuts just when it needs help the most
item.description: As of 2024, nine million people in South Sudan, or more than 70 per cent of the population, were dependent on some form of foreign assistance, according to the UN. Now, that dependence is colliding with shrinking resources and a hunger crisis.

item.title: Portugal to officially recognise State of Palestine
item.description: Portugal will officially recognise a Palestinian state, Portugal's foreign ministry said, ahead of a UN General Assembly where around ten other countries are set to follow suit.

item.title: Young orcas ram boats off Portugal's coast, sinking one
item.description: Two boats were rammed by a pod of young orcas recently off the coast of Portugal. One of the boats sank. Experts say it was play behaviour, but the whales caused quite the fright.

item.title: Indigenous Advisory Council appointments cause frustration
item.description: Chiefs in Manitoba say they’re concerned about the lack of a First Nations member from Manitoba on the federal Major Projects Office’s Indigenous Advisory Council.

item.title: The Traitors Ireland stars pick their winners
item.description: The Traitors Ireland stars Katelyn, Christine, and father and son Paudie and Andrew joined Patrick Kielty on Friday's Late Late Show to pick their winners as the excitement reaches fever pitch among fans.

item.title: Canada needs all evidence assessed before recognizing genocide in Gaza, says incoming UN ambassador
item.description: Incoming UN Ambassador David Lametti says Canada needs "all the evidence to come in" and be assessed before it can recognize whether Israel is committing a genocide in Gaza — and the first benchmark decisions are usually a UN resolution or a ruling from the International Court of Justice.

item.title: International students share cramped rental accommodation
item.description: Third level institutions in Limerick say that they are assisting up to 16 international students who have found themselves sharing in what was a two-bedroomed house.

item.title: Indigenous-led Downtown Eastside programs get 6-month funding extension
item.description: An Indigenous-led organization for unhoused residents of Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside says it has six more months to figure out how to continue drop-in services for its clients.

item.title: Podcast: Jimmy Kimmel suspension and phone data for sale
item.description: As the fallout from ABC's decision to suspend Jimmy Kimmel continues, several prominent US TV hosts used their platforms on Thursday night to criticise the decision to suspend him.

item.title: Bertie Ahern coy on support for Jim Gavin's Áras campaign
item.description: Former taoiseach Bertie Ahern was reluctant to express clear support when asked whether he would be giving his backing to Fianna Fáil's presidential candidate Jim Gavin, after his own bid for the party's nomination failed.

item.title: More to be done, but reconciliation with Indigenous communities on the right track, says Montreal
item.description: When its strategy for reconciliation with Indigenous people was launched in 2020, the Valérie Plante administration set out 125 actions to improve services and partnerships with these communities. Though some have noticed a shift in attitude, issues like red tape linger.

item.title: Global agreement to protect the oceans set to take effect after 60th ratification
item.description: The first treaty to protect marine diversity in international waters will come into force early next year, after Morocco became the 60th nation to ratify the agreement on Friday.

item.title: Trailblazing McPhillips ready for world final stage
item.description: It has been a week to remember for Cian McPhillips, lowering the 800m national record and making history by storming into a World Championship final. What can the Longford man hope to achieve at Japan's National Stadium?

item.title: U.S. vetoes U.N. ceasefire resolution as Gaza crisis deepens
item.description:
The United States has vetoed a UN Security Council resolution calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza and the release of hostages.

Read all

item.title: Pope invites Rome Diocese to promote pastoral ministry that welcomes all
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV addresses the clergy and faithful of the Diocese of Rome during an assembly at the Basilica of St John Lateran, inviting the Church of Rome to walk alongside the people of God with "a pastoral ministry that is supportive, empathetic, discreet, non-judgmental, and able to welcome everyone.”

Read all

item.title: FAI turns down committee invite after garda 'guidance'
item.description: The Football Association of Ireland has turned down a request to attend a Joint Oireachtas Committee on sport hearing next week, regarding safeguarding issues, on the basis that it "risks prejudicing ongoing garda investigations"

item.title: Post-mortem examination taking place on child's remains
item.description: A post-mortem examination is being carried out on partial skeletal remains of a child recovered from wasteland in Donabate in Co Dublin.

item.title: 'Questions to answer' over Troubles legacy deal - victims
item.description: A new deal to address the legacy of Northern Ireland's past, agreed by the UK and Irish governments, will have a lot of questions to answer, victims have said.

item.title: Initial World Cup ticket presale draws more than 4.5 million applicants worldwide
item.description: More than 4.5 million people worldwide applied for FIFA's initial 2026 World Cup ticket presale. It was the first crack at FIFA's worldwide ticket lottery for the 48-team tournament.

item.title: Pope Leo to celebrate Mass at the parish of St Anne in the Vatican
item.description:
The Holy See Press Office announces that the Pope will go to the ancient church located within Vatican City State to celebrate the 25th Sunday in Ordinary Time. The place of worship, which dates back to the 16th century, has been entrusted to the pastoral care of the Order of St. Augustine since 1929.

item.title: Minimum pay rates to increase for contract cleaners
item.description: Minimum rates of pay for workers in the contract cleaning sector are to increase under a new Employment Regulation Order.

item.title: Taylor Swift returning to theatres alongside launch of next album
item.description: U.S. chain AMC Theatres announced Friday that Taylor Swift: The Official Release Party of a Showgirl will hit theatres October 3, which is also the release date for her next album, The Life of A Showgirl.

item.title: Over 300 events taking place in Dublin for Culture Night
item.description: More than 300 events are taking place in the capital to mark Dublin's 25th Culture Night.

item.title: Safeguards for veterans could hinder Troubles legacy deal
item.description: The detail of legal safeguards for British military veterans will have a huge bearing on how nationalist political parties and victims' organisations in Northern Ireland judge a new agreement on dealing with the legacy of Northern Ireland's Troubles, writes Vincent Kearney

item.source:markdown: From the Faith & Science Resource Center (Younger Readers): the story of Jérôme Lejeune, who worked on chromosomal differences and Down Syndrome.

item.description: A British couple have been reunited with their family in Qatar after their release from nearly eight months of detention in a Taliban facility in Afghanistan.

item.description: Israel's military said it had expanded attacks on Gaza City as displaced Palestinians traumatised by the advance said they had no means to flee

item.title: High end luxury car models seized from M50 toll evaders
item.description: Mercedes Benz, BMW, Audi and Land Rover are some of the high end luxury car models that have been seized by the Dublin Sheriff from motorists to date this year who have racked up large bills concerning the non-payment on M50 tolls.

item.title: Kneecap to take legal action following Canadian ban
item.description: Irish rap trio Kneecap have said they are planning to take legal action against a member of the Canadian government for making statements about the band that they have branded "wholly untrue and deeply malicious".

item.title: New training program reaches out to under-represented, diverse filmmakers across Manitoba
item.description: A new — and free — film training program in Manitoba is being called revolutionary and the first of its kind in Canada.

item.title: Russian violation of Estonian airspace 'reckless' - NATO
item.description: NATO member Estonia's airspace was violated by three Russian military jets today, its government said, amid an increasingly tense atmosphere on the alliance's eastern flank.

item.title: Judge throws out Trump's $15B US lawsuit against the New York Times
item.description: A Florida federal judge on Friday tossed out a $15-billion US defamation lawsuit filed by U.S. President Donald Trump against the New York Times.

item.title: U.S. regulator sues Ticketmaster and Live Nation, alleging illegal resale tactics
item.description: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general sued Ticketmaster and its parent company on Thursday, saying they are forcing consumers to pay more to see live events through a variety of illegal tactics.

item.title: Paramilitary drone attack on mosque in Sudan kills at least 70 people, army says
item.description: A drone attack blamed on Sudan's paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces struck a mosque during prayers Friday, killing at least 70 worshippers in the North Darfur region, aid workers and the Sudanese army said.

item.title: Singer D4vd's shows cancelled amid investigation into body found in car
item.description: After the cancellation of a recent Seattle show, singer D4vd has appeared to cancel or suspend portions of his ongoing U.S. tour. The news comes shortly after a decomposed body was found inside an impounded Tesla in Los Angeles, identified as teenager Celeste Rivas — who went missing last year.

item.title: NATO, EU condemn Russia as Estonia says airspace was violated for 12 minutes
item.description: Estonia summoned a Russian diplomat to protest after three Russian fighter aircraft entered its airspace without permission Friday and stayed there for 12 minutes, an occurrence that the European Union said "further escalates tensions in the region."

item.title: Some athletes from Russia, Belarus can compete under neutral banner in Milan-Cortina Olympics
item.description: The International Olympic Committee will allow some individual athletes from Russia and Belarus to compete as neutral athletes at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics in February.

item.title: Chalk up a win for soft power as Donald Trump heads home from Britain happy
item.description: While Donald Trump's unusual second state visit to the U.K. this week appeared to be mostly about appealing to the U.S. president's ego, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer may have nudged Trump along on a couple of key points — notably Ukraine and Gaza.

item.title: Nepal: Church shares young people’s commitment to nation’s future
item.description:
Following recent unrest, calm has returned to Nepal as schools reopen and confidence grows in the transitional government, according to Fr. Silas Bogati, Apostolic Administrator of the Vicariate of Nepal.

item.title: SSE Airtricity to increase electricity prices by 9.5%
item.description: SSE Airtricity is to increase its standard variable electricity prices by 9.5% from next month, which will add around €150 annually onto a typical customer's bill.

item.title: RFK Jr.'s vaccine advisers change guidance around COVID shots, MMRV vaccines for young kids
item.description: The Friday vote takes a step back on recommending the COVID-19 shot — rather than recommending it outright for most adults as they have in the past, the panel voted that the vaccine should be available to everyone, and folks should make a personal decision about whether or not to get it alongside their doctor.

item.title: Govt and watchdog examining phone data revelations
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said the Government and the Data Protection Commissioner are examining revelations about the sale of Irish mobile phone location data.

item.title: Ignatius Maloyan: Armenian martyr soon to be saint
item.description:
Blessed Ignatius Maloyan, Archbishop of Mardin of the Armenian Catholics, is about to be proclaimed a Saint—an event marking a significant moment for the Armenian community and for the Catholic Church as a whole. The canonization Mass will take place in the Vatican on 19 October 2025.

item.title: ‘Tidal wave of emotion’ secures win for young Turkish writer in UN competition
item.description: Fifteen-year-old Reyyan Demiriz from Türkiye has been awarded first prize in a UN young writers’ competition which garnered a staggering 1.6 million entries from 65 different countries.
item.source:markdown: Fifteen-year-old Reyyan Demiriz from Türkiye has been awarded first prize in a UN young writers’ competition which garnered a staggering 1.6 million entries from 65 different countries.

item.title: UN backs Abbas video address after US visa refusal
item.description: The UN General Assembly on Friday adopted a resolution allowing Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas to address next week’s high-level debate by pre-recorded video after the United States refused to issue visas for Palestine’s delegation.

item.title: Israeli air strikes in south Lebanon violate UN resolution
item.description: The UN peacekeeping mission in Lebanon (UNIFIL) on Friday called on the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) to refrain from further strikes and fully withdraw from Lebanese territory after Israeli strikes endangered peacekeepers and civilians overnight.

item.title: UN Security Council rejects bid to continue Iran sanctions relief
item.description: A proposal to continue sanctions relief for Iran under the 2015 nuclear deal was rejected in the UN Security Council on Friday in a vote that revealed deep divisions over the so-called “snapback” process.

item.title: Sudan crisis: Surge in summary executions by all warring parties
item.description: At least 75 people have been killed, according to news reports, in a drone strike on a mosque during morning prayers in El Fasher city, in the west of the war-torn country.

item.title: UNICEF aid trucks robbed at gunpoint in Gaza City
item.description: Humanitarian aid in Gaza must be protected, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) said on Friday, following the theft of therapeutic food critical for saving thousands of young lives from malnutrition as famine spreads.

item.title: Afghanistan quake: Rescuers dodge dangers, women and girls face disaster, warns UN
item.description: Women and girls still reeling from Afghanistan's deadly earthquake face even greater suffering rebuilding their lives and livelihoods – with little help to hand, gender equality agency UN Women said on Friday.

item.title: Gazans flee ‘death and devastation’ with no transportation or means of shelter
item.description: In the face of escalating Israeli military operations, thousands of Palestinian families continue to flee the northern Gaza Strip amid dire humanitarian conditions and transportation shortages.

item.description:
Blessed Ignatius Maloyan, Archbishop of Mardin of the Armenian Catholics, is about to be proclaimed a Saint—an event marking a significant moment for the Armenian community and for the Catholic Church as a whole. The canonization Mass will take place in the Vatican on 19 October 2025.

item.title: Guardians of Creation: Children bring faith to life caring for our planet
item.description:
In Tucumán, Argentina, children are living their faith as Guardians of Creation, planting trees, mentoring peers, and learning to care for our planet through the Laudato Si’ initiative.”

item.title: What is Antifa and can the U.S. declare it a terrorist group?
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump says he wants to declare Antifa a major terrorist organization. But it's not clear whether he can even do that because though Antifa — short for anti-fascist — is a movement that exists around the world, it is not a single group.

item.title: Papua New Guinea awaits its first Saint: The story of Peter To Rot
item.description:
Catholics in Papua New Guinea feel they are living a historic moment. This October, the Catholic Church will canonize Blessed Peter To Rot, making him the nation’s first saint. The postulator for his cause sheds light on the saint and his story.

item.title: EU seeks to speed up phase-out of Russian gas imports
item.description: The European Union has proposed to bring forward a ban on Russian gas imports as part of a new package of sanctions aimed at sapping Moscow's war chest, and pleasing US President Donald Trump.

item.title: Pope Leo: God gave families the perfect model, the Holy Family
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV invites families to follow the example of the Holy Family, the 'perfect model' God offers us, and calls on them to rediscover the faith of their grandparents and parents which, through Jesus, brings true joy, in his remarks to participants in the Jubilee Meeting organized by the Latin American and Caribbean Episcopal Council (CELAM) on the future of the family.

item.title: Minimum wage rise 'nail in coffin' for businesses
item.description: The Low Pay Commission is expected to recommend to the Government an increase of 5% to the National Minimum Wage.

item.title: Man dies, another seriously injured after crash on N17
item.description: A man in his 20s has died after a collision between a car and a van on the Mayo/Galway border this morning.

item.title: Take That bringing Circus Tour back to Dublin next July
item.description: Take That are reviving their sell-out tour, The Circus Live, with 11 dates announced for stadiums across the UK and Ireland next summer - including one at Dublin's Aviva Stadium.

item.description:
Msgr. Daniel Pacho, Undersecretary for Multilateral Affairs at the Secretariat of State, addresses the 69th General Conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency, saying the rise in military expenditures represents an “affront to all humanity.”

item.title: Heptathlete O'Connor in medal hunt after trio of PBs
item.description: Kate O'Connor is firmly in the medal hunt in the heptathlon at the World Athletics Championship as Friday's four events produced three personal bests for the Irish athlete.

item.title: Sheridan fails to get Carlow County Council's nomination
item.description: Presidential hopeful Gareth Sheridan has failed to get a nomination from Carlow County Council.

item.title: Dominican sisters in Zimbabwe train young people in health sector
item.description:
For over 60 years, the Dominican Sisters in Zimbabwe have run St. Theresa Hospital in Chirimanzu, making a profound impact on the lives of young people by training them to become skilled primary care nurses and registered general nurses. Their legacy of compassion, education, and healthcare continues to shape the future of nursing in Zimbabwe.

Read all

item.title: Ukraine: Sisters of Blessed Honorat bind wounds of human suffering
item.description:
Founded to help people in need, the Little Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary are staying beside the people of Ukraine during the war, listening, comforting, and feeding those affected by the violence. “It does not matter to me whether I die in Poland or Ukraine, because my sisters and my community are there,” said Mother Judyta Kowalska, Superior General.

item.title: Saudi-Pakistan defence pact includes nuclear program, Pakistan defence minister says
item.description: Pakistan's defence minister has said that his nation's nuclear program "will be made available" to Saudi Arabia if needed under the countries' new defence pact.

item.title: A cry from eastern DR Congo: ‘Stop the massacres and bring peace’
item.description:
As violence continues in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the director of the “Missionary Families without Borders” association shares the pain of local residents as near-daily massacres take place in the eastern part of the country.

item.title: 'Literally speechless' - Father's pride on McPhillips win
item.description: The father of the Cian McPhillips, the first Irishman to qualify for a World Athletics Championships outdoor 800 metre final, has said he was "literally speechless" watching his son race yesterday.

item.title: 'It helped us cope' - Album honours those killed on roads
item.description: A Derry musician who lost his son in a road traffic collision has created a tribute album to honour children and young people who have died on Irish and Northern Irish roads.

item.title: Second group of Gazan students arrive in Ireland to study
item.description: A second group of students from Gaza have arrived in Ireland this morning to begin their studies at four universities here.

item.title: The best of Sean Rocks - classics from the Arena archives
item.description: For Culture Night 2025, we asked Guest Editor Belinda McKeon to select some highlights from the hundreds of interviews and performances hosted by Sean Rocks for RTÉ Arena over the years...

item.title: 58% of contactless payments made using mobile wallets
item.description: The use of smartphones and smartwatches, as the preferred payment method in Ireland, is continuing to grow.

item.title: Gardaí investigating burglary and arson at Dublin bar
item.description: An investigation is under way into a burglary and arson at a cocktail bar on Dawson Street in Dublin.

item.title: Israel shuts sole gateway from West Bank to Jordan after attack kills military personnel
item.description: Israel shut the sole gateway between the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Jordan on Friday, a day after a driver bringing humanitarian aid from Jordan for Gaza opened fire and killed two Israeli military personnel there.

item.title: Watch: House of Guinness cast on their best pint of plain
item.description: New Netflix series 'House of Guinness' premiered at the Lighthouse Cinema in Dublin last night with many of the main cast in attendance.

item.title: Wetlands providing natural treatment plant in Waterford
item.description: For a quarter of a century the village of Dunhill in Co Waterford has been using the magical power of wetlands to deal with its domestic wastewater, clean it up and safely release it back into the nearby River Anne.

item.title: NATO deterrence mission in Latvia drains the Canadian Army's fleet of vehicles
How a First Nation man is being remembered 1,200 km from his home community in northern Ontario
item.description: A member of Long Lake #58 First Nation in northern Ontario is being honoured in a display that's more than 1,200 kilometres away. Oxford County is remembering Percy Onabigon as his family plans to rebury him in his home community next week, after decades of fighting to repatriate his remains.

item.title: Trump says TV networks 'against' him could lose licences
item.description: US President Donald Trump has celebrated the suspension of talk-show host Jimmy Kimmel from the airwaves and said TV broadcasters should lose their licenses over negative coverage of his administration, adding fuel to a national debate over free speech.
